content: Paul Harvey On Deck! quote: "Washington is all in a tizzy and everybody is pointing fingers at each other and saying it's their fault, the Democrats' fault, the Republicans' fault," he said at a town hall meeting Wednesday. "Listen, I'll take responsibility. I'm the President." He also make clear that it isn't really his fault. "We didn't grant these contracts," he said. But he added: "So for everybody in Washington who's busy scrambling, trying to figure out how to blame somebody else, just go ahead and talk to me, because it's my job to make sure that we fix these messes, even if I don't make them." wow, more dbl talk......

content: I supported President Bush, I did not vote for President Obama, and I am certainly not happy with many of the decisions he has made so far; however, I must say, it was refreshing to see the President at least state that the buck stops with him. IMO, his failure to accept responsibility was one of the faults of President Bush (there were many, but I still think the good outweighed the bad). Now, for those on this board that just continue partisan attacks - you make yourself look ridiculous (you know, like jack flats always looks which is why it is difficult to take any post he makes as serious). There are many things you can complain about with the current POTUS, but this is not one of them. People from all parties should applaud this statement. Let's just hope it is not empty rhetoric. SCOUTS OUT!

content: RCcav - quote: There are many things you can complain about with the current POTUS, but this is not one of them. Well ... you have a bit of a point. However - it seems that every time POTUS 44 "takes responsibility", he immediately caveats it with "but it isn't my fault". quote: He also make clear that it isn't really his fault. "We didn't grant these contracts," he said. Now ... despite the political rhetoric that goes back and forth, most of us are smart enough to figure out what is really his fault ... and what isn't. Sometimes there is even enough "fault" to go around. In this case, there are at least four times when these pending bonuses should have surfaced - the first two FRB bailouts (spearheaded by ... Geithner during Bush's administration), the first Treasury bailout (purchase of 40 billion in stock) ... Paulson using TARP under Bush, and the second Treasury bailout using TARP ... Geithner under Obama. I would further suggest that Congress had at least three chances to get it right ... the first TARP bill that released 350 billion to Bush's administration ... the bill that released the second half of TARP to the Obama administration ... and HR1 that was rushed through so quickly that nobody of substance had time to read the final product. Those boys and girls in Congress, both the House and the Senate, get paid good bucks to do their damn job ... look ahead, read the crap they vote for, and practice oversight. They failed miserably on all counts. Obama's administration's fingerprints are all over the wording on executive compensation in the stimulus bill (HR1). Dodd, after backing off his Tuesday lie, admits to his involvement in the exception provision ... and lays it off on pressure from Obama's administration. Now ... had Obama stood up and said "My administration was responsible for the wording in the stimulus bill that gave AIG the technical grounds to honor their contractual obligation to pay bonuses - fool me once, shame on me ... it won't happen again" ... I'd be applauding. His "buck stops here but it really wasn't my fault", however, just doesn't get it.
quote: There are many things you can complain about with the current POTUS, but this is not one of them.

Those boys and girls in Congress, both the House and the Senate, get paid good bucks to do their damn job ... look ahead, read the crap they vote for, and practice oversight. They failed miserably on all counts. Obama's administration's fingerprints are all over the wording on executive compensation in the stimulus bill (HR1). Dodd, after backing off his Tuesday lie, admits to his involvement in the exception provision ... and lays it off on pressure from Obama's administration. Now ... had Obama stood up and said "My administration was responsible for the wording in the stimulus bill that gave AIG the technical grounds to honor their contractual obligation to pay bonuses - fool me once, shame on me ... it won't happen again" ... I'd be applauding. His "buck stops here but it really wasn't my fault", however, just doesn't get it.

content: quote: Originally posted by L0A1: quote: Originally posted by nspreitler: He should tell Senator Dodd to take responsibilty and resign. The Truman "buck stops here" attitude is great, and people want to hear it. However, it doesn't mean anything if nobody is held accountable. I was OK with Dodd ... until the liar lied ... and on camera no less. Nobody seems to have the intestinal fortitude to stand up for contractual law. AIG's bonuses were immoral in my view ... but, at least according to some legal analysts, legally binding. All the pre-Feb 11 exception did was recognize the supremacy of law. Dodd should resign ... not for the clause in the stimulus bill ... but for his blatant lie.

content: quote: Originally posted by SteveDeHaven: quote: Originally posted by Kegler300: He's not going to take responsibility for any part of this mess. He's only repeating what his teleprompter is telling him to say... What's all this "teleprompter" nonsense? Is that something Rush rants about? The previous office-filler couldn't even string two sentences together without sounding like an idiot. Still can't, in fact: quote: “I’m going to put people in my place, so when the history of this administration is written at least there’s an authoritarian voice saying exactly what happened.” (quoted from mightyredpen.wordpress(DOT)com/2009/03/18/bush-speaks-authoritative-vs-authoritarian/) Point taken ... but did we have to trade him in for someone even less well spoken? quote: "See, uhhh, I -- I -- eh -- Just one thing that, uhh, I was thinking about as I was, uhh, -- as I was -- getting off the, uhhh, copter 'cause, I -- uhhh -- you know, it was hard for me to believe you were entirely serious about that socialist question." <snip> "Uh, and so I think that, uh, it's important just to note, uhh, when you start, uhh, hearing folks, uhh, throw these words around, thaaat, um, uh, we've actually been operating, uh, in a way that, uh, is entirely consistent with free market principles, uh, and that, uhhh, uh, some of the same folks who are uh, throwing the word 'socialist' around can't say the same." And he wasn't done yet: "I -- I -- I -- I just think it's c-clear that by the time we had, uhhhhh. By the time we, eh, uh, got here, uhhh, ummm, there already had been, uh, an enormous infusion of taxpayer money into the financial system, aaand, eh, eh, eh, y-y-yuh-y-y-yuh.... The thing I constantly try to emphasize to people is that, if coming in the market was doing fine, nobody would be happier than me, uh, to stay out of it. Uh, you know, I -- I -- I have more than enough to do, uh, without having to worry about the financial system. Uh, and the fact that, uh, we've had to take these extraordinary measures, uh, and intervene, uh, is, uhh, not an indication of my ideological preferences."
quote: Originally posted by SteveDeHaven: quote: Originally posted by Kegler300: He's not going to take responsibility for any part of this mess. He's only repeating what his teleprompter is telling him to say... What's all this "teleprompter" nonsense? Is that something Rush rants about? The previous office-filler couldn't even string two sentences together without sounding like an idiot. Still can't, in fact: quote: “I’m going to put people in my place, so when the history of this administration is written at least there’s an authoritarian voice saying exactly what happened.” (quoted from mightyredpen.wordpress(DOT)com/2009/03/18/bush-speaks-authoritative-vs-authoritarian/)
reply: Point taken ... but did we have to trade him in for someone even less well spoken? quote: "See, uhhh, I -- I -- eh -- Just one thing that, uhh, I was thinking about as I was, uhh, -- as I was -- getting off the, uhhh, copter 'cause, I -- uhhh -- you know, it was hard for me to believe you were entirely serious about that socialist question." <snip> "Uh, and so I think that, uh, it's important just to note, uhh, when you start, uhh, hearing folks, uhh, throw these words around, thaaat, um, uh, we've actually been operating, uh, in a way that, uh, is entirely consistent with free market principles, uh, and that, uhhh, uh, some of the same folks who are uh, throwing the word 'socialist' around can't say the same." And he wasn't done yet: "I -- I -- I -- I just think it's c-clear that by the time we had, uhhhhh. By the time we, eh, uh, got here, uhhh, ummm, there already had been, uh, an enormous infusion of taxpayer money into the financial system, aaand, eh, eh, eh, y-y-yuh-y-y-yuh.... The thing I constantly try to emphasize to people is that, if coming in the market was doing fine, nobody would be happier than me, uh, to stay out of it. Uh, you know, I -- I -- I have more than enough to do, uh, without having to worry about the financial system. Uh, and the fact that, uh, we've had to take these extraordinary measures, uh, and intervene, uh, is, uhh, not an indication of my ideological preferences."

content: I supported President Bush, I did not vote for President Obama, and I am certainly not happy with many of the decisions he has made so far; however, I must say, it was refreshing to see the President at least state that the buck stops with him. IMO, his failure to accept responsibility was one of the faults of President Bush (there were many, but I still think the good outweighed the bad). Now, for those on this board that just continue partisan attacks - you make yourself look ridiculous (you know, like jack flats always looks which is why it is difficult to take any post he makes as serious). There are many things you can complain about with the current POTUS, but this is not one of them. People from all parties should applaud this statement. Let's just hope it is not empty rhetoric. SCOUTS OUT!

content: RCcav - quote: There are many things you can complain about with the current POTUS, but this is not one of them. Well ... you have a bit of a point. However - it seems that every time POTUS 44 "takes responsibility", he immediately caveats it with "but it isn't my fault". quote: He also make clear that it isn't really his fault. "We didn't grant these contracts," he said. Now ... despite the political rhetoric that goes back and forth, most of us are smart enough to figure out what is really his fault ... and what isn't. Sometimes there is even enough "fault" to go around. In this case, there are at least four times when these pending bonuses should have surfaced - the first two FRB bailouts (spearheaded by ... Geithner during Bush's administration), the first Treasury bailout (purchase of 40 billion in stock) ... Paulson using TARP under Bush, and the second Treasury bailout using TARP ... Geithner under Obama. I would further suggest that Congress had at least three chances to get it right ... the first TARP bill that released 350 billion to Bush's administration ... the bill that released the second half of TARP to the Obama administration ... and HR1 that was rushed through so quickly that nobody of substance had time to read the final product. Those boys and girls in Congress, both the House and the Senate, get paid good bucks to do their damn job ... look ahead, read the crap they vote for, and practice oversight. They failed miserably on all counts. Obama's administration's fingerprints are all over the wording on executive compensation in the stimulus bill (HR1). Dodd, after backing off his Tuesday lie, admits to his involvement in the exception provision ... and lays it off on pressure from Obama's administration. Now ... had Obama stood up and said "My administration was responsible for the wording in the stimulus bill that gave AIG the technical grounds to honor their contractual obligation to pay bonuses - fool me once, shame on me ... it won't happen again" ... I'd be applauding. His "buck stops here but it really wasn't my fault", however, just doesn't get it.
quote: There are many things you can complain about with the current POTUS, but this is not one of them.
reply: RCcav -  Well ... you have a bit of a point. However - it seems that every time POTUS 44 "takes responsibility", he immediately caveats it with "but it isn't my fault". quote: He also make clear that it isn't really his fault. Geithner during Bush's administration), the first Treasury bailout (purchase of 40 billion in stock) ... Paulson using TARP under Bush, and the second Treasury bailout using TARP ... Geithner under Obama. I would further suggest that Congress had at least three chances to get it right ... the first TARP bill that released 350 billion to Bush's administration ... the bill that released the second half of TARP to the Obama administration ... and HR1 that was rushed through so quickly that nobody of substance had time to read the final product. Those boys and girls in Congress, both the House and the Senate, get paid good bucks to do their damn job ... look ahead, read the crap they vote for, and practice oversight. They failed miserably on all counts. Obama's administration's fingerprints are all over the wording on executive compensation in the stimulus bill (HR1). Now ... had Obama stood up and said "My administration was responsible for the wording in the stimulus bill that gave AIG the technical grounds to honor their contractual obligation to pay bonuses - fool me once, shame on me ... it won't happen again" ... I'd be applauding. His "buck stops here but it really wasn't my fault", however, just doesn't get it.

content: quote: Originally posted by L0A1: quote: Originally posted by nspreitler: He should tell Senator Dodd to take responsibilty and resign. The Truman "buck stops here" attitude is great, and people want to hear it. However, it doesn't mean anything if nobody is held accountable. I was OK with Dodd ... until the liar lied ... and on camera no less. Nobody seems to have the intestinal fortitude to stand up for contractual law. AIG's bonuses were immoral in my view ... but, at least according to some legal analysts, legally binding. All the pre-Feb 11 exception did was recognize the supremacy of law. Dodd should resign ... not for the clause in the stimulus bill ... but for his blatant lie.

content: quote: Originally posted by SteveDeHaven: quote: Originally posted by Kegler300: He's not going to take responsibility for any part of this mess. He's only repeating what his teleprompter is telling him to say... What's all this "teleprompter" nonsense? Is that something Rush rants about? The previous office-filler couldn't even string two sentences together without sounding like an idiot. Still can't, in fact: quote: “I’m going to put people in my place, so when the history of this administration is written at least there’s an authoritarian voice saying exactly what happened.” (quoted from mightyredpen.wordpress(DOT)com/2009/03/18/bush-speaks-authoritative-vs-authoritarian/) Point taken ... but did we have to trade him in for someone even less well spoken? quote: "See, uhhh, I -- I -- eh -- Just one thing that, uhh, I was thinking about as I was, uhh, -- as I was -- getting off the, uhhh, copter 'cause, I -- uhhh -- you know, it was hard for me to believe you were entirely serious about that socialist question." <snip> "Uh, and so I think that, uh, it's important just to note, uhh, when you start, uhh, hearing folks, uhh, throw these words around, thaaat, um, uh, we've actually been operating, uh, in a way that, uh, is entirely consistent with free market principles, uh, and that, uhhh, uh, some of the same folks who are uh, throwing the word 'socialist' around can't say the same." And he wasn't done yet: "I -- I -- I -- I just think it's c-clear that by the time we had, uhhhhh. By the time we, eh, uh, got here, uhhh, ummm, there already had been, uh, an enormous infusion of taxpayer money into the financial system, aaand, eh, eh, eh, y-y-yuh-y-y-yuh.... The thing I constantly try to emphasize to people is that, if coming in the market was doing fine, nobody would be happier than me, uh, to stay out of it. Uh, you know, I -- I -- I have more than enough to do, uh, without having to worry about the financial system. Uh, and the fact that, uh, we've had to take these extraordinary measures, uh, and intervene, uh, is, uhh, not an indication of my ideological preferences."
quote: Originally posted by SteveDeHaven: quote: Originally posted by Kegler300: He's not going to take responsibility for any part of this mess. He's only repeating what his teleprompter is telling him to say... What's all this "teleprompter" nonsense? Is that something Rush rants about? The previous office-filler couldn't even string two sentences together without sounding like an idiot. Still can't, in fact: quote: “I’m going to put people in my place, so when the history of this administration is written at least there’s an authoritarian voice saying exactly what happened.” (quoted from mightyredpen.wordpress(DOT)com/2009/03/18/bush-speaks-authoritative-vs-authoritarian/)
reply: Point taken ... but did we have to trade him in for someone even less well spoken? quote: "See, uhhh, I -- I -- eh -- Just one thing that, uhh, I was thinking about as I was, uhh, -- as I was -- getting off the, uhhh, copter 'cause, I -- uhhh -- you know, it was hard for me to believe you were entirely serious about that socialist question." <snip> "Uh, and so I think that, uh, it's important just to note, uhh, when you start, uhh, hearing folks, uhh, throw these words around, thaaat, um, uh, we've actually been operating, uh, in a way that, uh, is entirely consistent with free market principles, uh, and that, uhhh, uh, some of the same folks who are uh, throwing the word 'socialist' around can't say the same." And he wasn't done yet: "I -- I -- I -- I just think it's c-clear that by the time we had, uhhhhh. By the time we, eh, uh, got here, uhhh, ummm, there already had been, uh, an enormous infusion of taxpayer money into the financial system, aaand, eh, eh, eh, y-y-yuh-y-y-yuh.... The thing I constantly try to emphasize to people is that, if coming in the market was doing fine, nobody would be happier than me, uh, to stay out of it. Uh, you know, I -- I -- I have more than enough to do, uh, without having to worry about the financial system. Uh, and the fact that, uh, we've had to take these extraordinary measures, uh, and intervene, uh, is, uhh, not an indication of my ideological preferences."

quote: Originally posted by Irwin_R_Schyster: Thats his job....too take responsibility, whether it is his fault or not. Our Dear Decider never had the intestinal fortitude to do the same.....
reply: I have to agree with you there. Todays politics remind me of an old saying. - "Ideas are more powerful than guns. We would not let our enemies have guns, why should we let them have ideas?" - Joseph Stalin
title: President Obama "I'll Take Responsibility"

content: quote: Originally posted by GunnyRet03: Paul Harvey On Deck! quote: "Washington is all in a tizzy and everybody is pointing fingers at each other and saying it's their fault, the Democrats' fault, the Republicans' fault," he said at a town hall meeting Wednesday. "Listen, I'll take responsibility. I'm the President." He also make clear that it isn't really his fault. "We didn't grant these contracts," he said. But he added: "So for everybody in Washington who's busy scrambling, trying to figure out how to blame somebody else, just go ahead and talk to me, because it's my job to make sure that we fix these messes, even if I don't make them." wow, more dbl talk...... Big Chief 0bama speaks with forked tongue....

content: I heard it put best: "He's offering, while totally innocent, to accept responsibility and for our "sins". (But we know he's not a Messiah. He can't even make a cabinet.)
reply: I heard it put best: "He's offering, while totally innocent, to accept responsibility and for our "sins". (But we know he's not a Messiah. He can't even make a cabinet.)
title: President Obama "I'll Take Responsibility"

content: quote: Originally posted by L0A1: quote: Originally posted by nspreitler: He should tell Senator Dodd to take responsibilty and resign. The Truman "buck stops here" attitude is great, and people want to hear it. However, it doesn't mean anything if nobody is held accountable. I was OK with Dodd ... until the liar lied ... and on camera no less. Nobody seems to have the intestinal fortitude to stand up for contractual law. AIG's bonuses were immoral in my view ... but, at least according to some legal analysts, legally binding. All the pre-Feb 11 exception did was recognize the supremacy of law. Dodd should resign ... not for the clause in the stimulus bill ... but for his blatant lie.
quote: Originally posted by L0A1: quote: Originally posted by nspreitler: He should tell Senator Dodd to take responsibilty and resign. The Truman "buck stops here" attitude is great, and people want to hear it. However, it doesn't mean anything if nobody is held accountable.

AIG's bonuses were immoral in my view ... but, at least according to some legal analysts, legally binding. All the pre-Feb 11 exception did was recognize the supremacy of law. Dodd should resign ... not for the clause in the stimulus bill ... but for his blatant lie.

Still can't, in fact: quote: “I’m going to put people in my place, so when the history of this administration is written at least there’s an authoritarian voice saying exactly what happened.” (quoted from mightyredpen.wordpress(DOT)com/2009/03/18/bush-speaks-authoritative-vs-authoritarian/)

content: quote: Originally posted by SteveDeHaven: quote: Originally posted by Kegler300: He's not going to take responsibility for any part of this mess. He's only repeating what his teleprompter is telling him to say... What's all this "teleprompter" nonsense? Is that something Rush rants about? The previous office-filler couldn't even string two sentences together without sounding like an idiot. Still can't, in fact: quote: “I’m going to put people in my place, so when the history of this administration is written at least there’s an authoritarian voice saying exactly what happened.” (quoted from mightyredpen.wordpress(DOT)com/2009/03/18/bush-speaks-authoritative-vs-authoritarian/) Point taken ... but did we have to trade him in for someone even less well spoken? quote: "See, uhhh, I -- I -- eh -- Just one thing that, uhh, I was thinking about as I was, uhh, -- as I was -- getting off the, uhhh, copter 'cause, I -- uhhh -- you know, it was hard for me to believe you were entirely serious about that socialist question." <snip> "Uh, and so I think that, uh, it's important just to note, uhh, when you start, uhh, hearing folks, uhh, throw these words around, thaaat, um, uh, we've actually been operating, uh, in a way that, uh, is entirely consistent with free market principles, uh, and that, uhhh, uh, some of the same folks who are uh, throwing the word 'socialist' around can't say the same." And he wasn't done yet: "I -- I -- I -- I just think it's c-clear that by the time we had, uhhhhh. By the time we, eh, uh, got here, uhhh, ummm, there already had been, uh, an enormous infusion of taxpayer money into the financial system, aaand, eh, eh, eh, y-y-yuh-y-y-yuh.... The thing I constantly try to emphasize to people is that, if coming in the market was doing fine, nobody would be happier than me, uh, to stay out of it. Uh, you know, I -- I -- I have more than enough to do, uh, without having to worry about the financial system. Uh, and the fact that, uh, we've had to take these extraordinary measures, uh, and intervene, uh, is, uhh, not an indication of my ideological preferences."
quote: Originally posted by SteveDeHaven: quote: Originally posted by Kegler300: He's not going to take responsibility for any part of this mess. He's only repeating what his teleprompter is telling him to say... What's all this "teleprompter" nonsense? Is that something Rush rants about? The previous office-filler couldn't even string two sentences together without sounding like an idiot. Still can't, in fact: quote: “I’m going to put people in my place, so when the history of this administration is written at least there’s an authoritarian voice saying exactly what happened.” (quoted from mightyredpen.wordpress(DOT)com/2009/03/18/bush-speaks-authoritative-vs-authoritarian/)
reply: Point taken ... but did we have to trade him in for someone even less well spoken? quote: "See, uhhh, I -- I -- eh -- Just one thing that, uhh, I was thinking about as I was, uhh, -- as I was -- getting off the, uhhh, copter 'cause, I -- uhhh -- you know, it was hard for me to believe you were entirely serious about that socialist question." <snip> "Uh, and so I think that, uh, it's important just to note, uhh, when you start, uhh, hearing folks, uhh, throw these words around, thaaat, um, uh, we've actually been operating, uh, in a way that, uh, is entirely consistent with free market principles, uh, and that, uhhh, uh, some of the same folks who are uh, throwing the word 'socialist' around can't say the same." And he wasn't done yet: "I -- I -- I -- I just think it's c-clear that by the time we had, uhhhhh. By the time we, eh, uh, got here, uhhh, ummm, there already had been, uh, an enormous infusion of taxpayer money into the financial system, aaand, eh, eh, eh, y-y-yuh-y-y-yuh.... The thing I constantly try to emphasize to people is that, if coming in the market was doing fine, nobody would be happier than me, uh, to stay out of it. Uh, you know, I -- I -- I have more than enough to do, uh, without having to worry about the financial system. Uh, and the fact that, uh, we've had to take these extraordinary measures, uh, and intervene, uh, is, uhh, not an indication of my ideological preferences."
title: President Obama "I'll Take Responsibility"
